skills.name: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places
Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 3 or more decimal places
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 1 decimal place to fractions
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 3 or more decimal places to fractions
Convert terminating decimals greater than 1 to fractions

explanations.A: If you divide 5 by 8 you would get a number less than 1. Use the place value of the digits to write the fraction
explanations.B: The decimal point isn't the same as a fraction line. Use the place value of the digits to write the fraction
explanations.C: You are really close, just remember to simplify
explanations.D: 1.6 is equal to 16 tenths or 16/10, which is equivalent to 8/5.

explanations.A: 1.4 is the same as 14 tenths or 14/10 which equals 7/5.
explanations.B: If you divide 5 by 7 you would get a number less than 1. Use the place value of the digits to write the fraction
explanations.C: Really close, just remember to simplify the fraction
explanations.D: If you divide 10 by 14 you would get a number less than 1. Use the place value of the digits to write the fraction

explanations.A: You are really close! Use this equivalent fraction to help you write your answer as a decimal.
explanations.C: If it was 19/100 that would be right, but the denominator is 20. Try writing an equivalent fraction over 100, and then you can change it into a decimal.
explanations.D: I think you found the nearest tenth. Try writing an equivalent fraction over 100, and then you can change it into a decimal.

explanations.B: You are really close! Use this equivalent fraction to help you write your answer as a decimal.
explanations.C: If it was 13/100 that would be right, but the denominator is 20. Try writing an equivalent fraction over 100, and then you can change it into a decimal.
explanations.D: I think you found the nearest tenth. Try writing an equivalent fraction over 100, and then you can change it into a decimal.

explanations.A: You are really close. Just remember to simplify the fraction.
explanations.B: You are really close. Just remember to simplify the fraction.
explanations.C: 0.8 is 8 tenths or 8/10. When we simplify this by dividing the numerator and denominator by 2, we get the answer 4/5.
explanations.D: The 8 after the decimal point doesn't tell us the denominator. Think about the place value of the 8, this will help you to write the fraction.

explanations.A: 0.6 is 6 tenths or 6/10. When we simplify this by dividing the numerator and denominator by 2, we get the answer 3/5.
explanations.B: The 6 after the decimal point doesn't tell us the denominator. Think about the place value of the 6, this will help you to write the fraction.
explanations.C: You are really close. Just remember to simplify the fraction.
explanations.D: You are really close. Just remember to simplify the fraction.

explanations.A: I think you have only used the denominator, but you need to take the numerator into account too. Remember that the fraction line means divide
explanations.B: I think you have only used the numerator, but you need to take the denominator into account too. Remember that the fraction line means divide
explanations.C: To go from a fraction to a decimal you can't just put the digits after the decimal. You need to divide the numerator by the denominator
explanations.D: The fraction 7/8 is equivalent to 7 ÷ 8. Put 7.000 in the ‘bus-stop’ and 8 outside. The number 8 doesn't go into 7, so the answer begins ‘0.’ and the 7 is carried over to give the next calculation of 70 ÷ 8 = 8 remainder 6. There is now ‘0.8’ written above the bus-stop. The 6 is carried over for the next calculation of 60 ÷ 8 = 7 remainder 4 (giving ‘0.87’ as an answer so far). The next stage is 40 ÷ 8 = 5, which completes the calculation because there are no remainders. So 7/8 = 0.875

explanations.A: I think you have only used the numerator, but you need to take the denominator into account too. Remember that the fraction line means divide
explanations.B: To go from a fraction to a decimal you can't just put the digits after the decimal. You need to divide the numerator by the denominator
explanations.C: The fraction 3/8 is equivalent to 3 ÷ 8. Put 3.000 in the ‘bus-stop’ and 8 outside. The number 8 doesn’t go into 3, so the answer begins ‘0.’ and the next calculation is 30 ÷ 8 = 3 remainder 6 (and the answer now begins ‘0.3’). This 6 is carried over for the next calculation of 60 ÷ 8 = 7 remainder 4. The next stage is 40 ÷ 8 = 5, which completes the calculation because there are no remainders. So 3/8 = 0.375
explanations.D: To go from a fraction to a decimal you need to divide the numerator by the denominator. Try using a bus stop method.

explanations.A: Not quite. Think about the place value of the 9. What column is it in?
explanations.B: Not quite. The 9 tells us about the numerator, it is the place value that tells us about the denominator.
explanations.C: The 9 is in the thousandths column, so we have 9 thousandths, or 9/1000
explanations.D: Nearly. Just double check the place value column the 9 is in.

explanations.A: Not quite. Think about the place value of the 3. What column is it in?
explanations.B: The 3 is in the thousandths column, so we have 3 thousandths, or 3/1000
explanations.C: Nearly. Just double check the place value column the 3 is in.
explanations.D: Not quite. The 3 tells us about the numerator, it is the place value that tells us about the denominator.
